Completion Prompts: Name one recurring conflict pattern you see.
Write a short note owning your part in that pattern and a concrete behavior you will change.
Identify one new response you will try next time the pattern arises, and add a reminder.

Primary Scenarios: A recurring conflict arises in a startup team and needs to be learned from, not repeated.

Overall Outcomes.Excellent: Understands the systemic drivers of conflict and makes intentional shifts.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Recognizes recurring patterns and begins naming them.
Overall Outcomes.Poor: Treats conflict as isolated events; repeats the same fights.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Transforms conflict into a teacher that strengthens relationships and the field.

Overall Purpose: To reveal and integrate the recurring patterns beneath conflict so they do not repeat unconsciously.

Guiding Questions: What keeps showing up in our conflicts?
When and where does it activate most reliably?
What exits from the pattern have worked before?
Themes.Name: Noticing the Repetition

Excellent.Example moves: Create a one-page pattern map with conditions and exits.
Excellent.Future effect: Team anticipates and routes around triggers.
Excellent.Present pattern: Maps when/where patterns activate and why.
Excellent.Signals: Calmer tone; earlier flagging of risk.

Expected.30-90 day system effect: Energy begins to stabilize; fewer surprises.
Expected.Edge condition: Avoid shaming yourself or others for patterns.
Expected.Example moves: Jot a quick ‘pattern snapshot’ after tense moments.

Poor.30-90 day system effect: Patterns repeat; stress accumulates across cycles.
Poor.Future effect: Repetition entrenches and expands into more areas.
Poor.Immediate cost: Keeps reacting the same way; no learning loop.
Poor.Present pattern: Sees each conflict as separate and situational.
Poor.Signals: Déjà vu; same arguments; same roles in fights.

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: System adjusts; conflicts reduce at the root.
Transcendent.Example moves: Turn the map into two small structural experiments.
Transcendent.Future effect: Organization gets better at learning from conflict.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Reads repetition as a field-level signal for design change.
Transcendent.Signals: Smoother handoffs; fewer flare-ups across teams.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To identify where patterns recur across conflicts.
Themes.Why This Matters: Awareness is the first step to breaking cycles.

Guiding Questions: What past dynamics does this echo?
What small change would relieve pressure quickly?
Themes.Name: Tracing the Roots

Excellent.Edge condition: Don’t over-engineer the system all at once.
Excellent.Example moves: Pilot one policy or ritual to address a top root.
Excellent.Present pattern: Maps roots to specific interventions and agreements.

Expected.Example moves: Write a short roots statement with evidence.
Expected.Future effect: Better levers for change become visible.
Expected.Immediate cost: Vulnerability to look honestly at self and system.
Expected.Present pattern: Considers deeper origins alongside surface events.
Expected.Signals: Balanced analysis of roles and conditions.

Poor.30-90 day system effect: Root causes remain untouched; frustration deepens.
Poor.Example moves: Name one personal, one relational, one systemic contributor.
Poor.Present pattern: Blames surface events or people only.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Sees roots as invitations to mature the field.
Transcendent.Signals: People flag roots early without blame.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To explore personal, relational, and systemic roots of the pattern.
Themes.Why This Matters: Roots often go unseen but shape present dynamics.

Guiding Questions: What part do I reliably play here?
What is one behavior I will change next time?
What cue will help me notice in time?
Themes.Name: Owning My Part

Excellent.Present pattern: Builds a personal interrupt for the trigger moment.
Excellent.Signals: You catch yourself earlier; teammates mirror.

Expected.Example moves: Share your change with timing and metric.
Expected.Future effect: New options appear in the moment.
Expected.Present pattern: Names a specific contribution and a small change.

Poor.30-90 day system effect: Trust erodes; others harden their stance.
Poor.Edge condition: Avoid confession theater; keep it specific.
Poor.Example moves: Write one sentence owning your part and one behavior you’ll change.
Poor.Future effect: Patterns harden around roles (‘the blocker’, ‘the savior’).

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: System learns to adjust quickly after misses.
Transcendent.Future effect: Repair becomes reflexive in the field.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Turns ownership into a cultural pattern of repair.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To acknowledge personal contribution to the pattern and choose a shift.
Themes.Why This Matters: Taking responsibility unlocks change and invites reciprocity.

Guiding Questions: What is the other person protecting or caring for?
What are they right about that I can name?
What shared constraint are we both living inside?
Themes.Name: Seeing the Other Clearly

Excellent.Example moves: Name one thing they’re right about.

Expected.Example moves: Summarize their view and confirm accuracy.
Expected.Immediate cost: Time and patience to get it right.

Poor.Example moves: Ask: ‘What need are you protecting right now?’

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: Conflict illuminates how the system shapes behavior.
Transcendent.Edge condition: Avoid dissolving accountability into the ether.
Transcendent.Example moves: Map the shared constraint you both feel.
Transcendent.Present pattern: Sees the other as mirror of shared field conditions.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To recognize the other’s perspective and legitimate needs.
Themes.Why This Matters: Mutual recognition interrupts projection and softens cycles.

Guiding Questions: What smallest whole move can we try next time?
How will we remember in the hot moment?
What metric would tell us it worked?
Themes.Name: Designing a New Response

Excellent.30-90 day system effect: Conflicts end sooner; fewer cross-team ripples.
Excellent.Example moves: Write the 3-step interrupt you’ll use and share it.
Excellent.Present pattern: Builds a tiny protocol for trigger moments.

Expected.Example moves: Add a calendar nudge + peer checkpoint.
Expected.Present pattern: Picks a reversible step and a reminder.

Poor.Example moves: Define one reversible move you will actually try.
Poor.Present pattern: Falls into familiar reactions without supports.
Poor.Signals: ‘Here we go again’ scripts; weekend slacks.

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: System carries less conflict debt overall.
Transcendent.Edge condition: Avoid turning it into control theater.
Transcendent.Example moves: Document the norm once it sticks; keep it light.
Transcendent.Signals: Others mirror the interrupt; calmer field.

Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To choose practical moves that interrupt the pattern next time.
Themes.Why This Matters: Without new responses, awareness drifts back into habit.

Title: Learning the Pattern Behind the Conflict
When To Use This Protocol: After or during conflict when the same tensions seem to recur without resolution.
Why This Matters: Conflict often replays deeper patterns. Seeing them clearly allows choice, repair, and future coherence.
